events.originalText: The Provisional Irish Republican Army announced the formal end of its armed campaign to overthrow British rule in Northern Ireland and create a united Ireland.
events.subtitle: Provisional Irish Republican Army
events.headline: Provisional Irish Republican Army Ends Armed Campaign in Northern Ireland

events.originalText: At the World Aquatics Championships in Fukuoka, Japan, Australian Ian Thorpe  became the first swimmer to win six gold medals at a single FINA world championship.
events.subtitle: 2001 World Aquatics Championships
events.headline: Ian Thorpe Makes History with Six Gold Medals at World Aquatics Championships

events.originalText: Two followers of the Indian mystic Rajneesh were convicted of a 1985 plot to assassinate Charles Turner, the U.S. attorney for the District of Oregon.
events.subtitle: Rajneesh movement
events.headline: Indian Mystic Rajneesh Followers Convicted in Assassination Plot

events.originalText: An earthquake registering 7.6 Mw, one of the deadliest in history, devastated Tangshan, China, and killed at least 240,000 people.
events.subtitle: 1976 Tangshan earthquake
events.headline: Deadly Earthquake Devastates Tangshan, China, Killing 240,000

events.originalText: A B-25 bomber crashed into the Empire State Building in New York City, killing 14 people and causing an estimated $1 million in damage.
events.subtitle: North American B-25 Mitchell
events.headline: B-25 Bomber Crashes into Empire State Building, 14 Dead

events.originalText: At the Salzburg Conference, German dictator Adolf Hitler demanded the replacement of much of Slovakia's cabinet.
events.subtitle: Salzburg Conference
events.headline: Hitler Demands Cabinet Replacement in Slovakia at Salzburg Conference

events.originalText: During the excavation of a 7th-century ship burial at Sutton Hoo in Suffolk, England, archaeologists discovered a helmet that is widely associated with King Rædwald of East Anglia.
events.subtitle: Ship burial
events.headline: Archaeologists Discover Helmet Linked to King Rædwald at Sutton Hoo

events.originalText: The Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress heavy bomber, which dropped more bombs than any other U.S. aircraft in World War II, made its first flight.
events.subtitle: Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress
events.headline: Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress Makes First Flight

events.originalText: In New York City, the NAACP and church and community leaders organized a silent march (newsreel footage featured) of at least 8,000 people to protest violence directed towards African Americans.
events.subtitle: NAACP
events.headline: NAACP Organizes Silent March in NYC to Protest Violence Against African Americans

events.originalText: The Australasian Antarctic Expedition began with the departure of SY Aurora (pictured) from London.
events.subtitle: Australasian Antarctic Expedition
events.headline: Australasian Antarctic Expedition Begins with Departure of SY Aurora

events.originalText: At the age of 18, Vinnie Ream became the youngest artist and first woman to receive a commission from the United States government for a statue—that of Abraham Lincoln currently in the U.S. Capitol rotunda.
events.subtitle: Vinnie Ream
events.headline: Vinnie Ream Becomes Youngest Artist Commissioned by U.S. Government for Lincoln Statue

events.originalText: Peruvian War of Independence: Argentine general José de San Martín declared the independence of Peru from the Spanish Empire.
events.subtitle: Peruvian War of Independence
events.headline: General José de San Martín Declares Independence of Peru from Spanish Empire

events.originalText: Crusades: The siege of Damascus ended in a decisive victory for the Muslims, leading to the disintegration of the Second Crusade.
events.subtitle: Crusades
events.headline: Siege of Damascus Ends in Victory for Muslims, Second Crusade Disintegrates
